title: Kaos and the Trump Spac
text:
In today's newsletter:

  • Behind Rocket One Capital

  • A €9.7bn offer for EDF 

  • Twitter vs Musk set for October 

The Rocket man involved in the Trump Spac 

Rocket One Capital was a relatively unknown investment firm.

That is until it made an appearance in a regulatory filing from Digital World Acquisition Corp, the “blank cheque” company that is set to merge with Donald Trump's nascent social media venture.

DWAC, which has agreed to take public Trump Media and Technology Group, disclosed in June that federal prosecutors are investigating its ties with Rocket One.

The Miami-based firm was an early investor in the Spac, and one of its executives (until recently) had a place on DWAC's board.

Bruce Garelick, who is Rocket One's chief strategy officer, was nominated as a director last year, ahead of the Spac's initial public offering.

He resigned from the board last month, a few days after DWAC and its directors received a batch of subpoenas from a federal grand jury in New York.

The man behind Rocket One is Michael Shvartsman, who was born in the Ukrainian port city of Odesa and spent most of his early life in Canada. There he helped run a nightclub called Kaos, which had its fair share of run-ins with the Edmonton police.

You'll find all the colourful details in this report by DD's Mark Vandevelde and Ortenca Aliaj.

Shvartsman filed a lawsuit against the cops, claiming they were trying to put the club out of business by maliciously spreading false information about the venue. The lawsuit was dismissed without any finding being made as to the truth of the allegations made by the police. Shvartsman hasn't been accused of any wrongdoing.

Prosecutors in the southern district of New York didn't respond to questions about the reasons for their interest in Rocket One.

Garelick couldn't be reached for comment. A representative for Shvartsman didn't provide a comment on the Department of Justice subpoenas.

Kaos folded in 1999 and Shvartsman later moved to Florida, where he has built an eclectic collection of business interests spanning payments, patio furniture and a recruitment platform for migrants.

Among them is Rocket One. “What initially started as a family office has turned into a venture capital firm,” its website stated before it was removed in the hours after the subpoenas became public.

Rocket One invested in DWAC alongside ordinary investors in the company's September IPO, according to a person familiar with the transaction. The company's shares increased from $10 to $94 after the Trump deal was announced, before falling back as potential legal obstacles to the transaction have grown.

Now, DWAC says that an investigation by federal prosecutors could delay its deal with Trump's media group. It is unclear where that leaves the Trump venture's $1bn in expected proceeds, or the aspirations of investors such as Shvartsman.

French power politics

EDF is close to ending 17 precarious years as a public company with a €9.7bn offer from the French government, which will bring the company under full state control.

For some it has been a long time coming.

The French power group's long-suffering shareholders have seen its stock price shrivel by 60 per cent since its IPO in 2005. Its largest investor — the government, which holds an 84 per cent stake — has sometimes made contradicting demands on the company.

As recently as January, the state forced EDF to pay for price caps it introduced to protect consumers from soaring electricity costs. The company lost a fifth of its market value as a result.

While most of the market has reacted positively to the government's plans to nationalise EDF, some retail investors are crying foul and pushing back against a tender offer they say leaves them nursing losses at €12 a share. One association representing some EDF employee shareholders is attempting to sue.

But this sort of opposition should be relatively easy to overcome if the government reaches a 90 per cent acceptance threshold once it launches the offer at the end of September.

A potentially bigger hurdle to getting the buyout done quickly could come from another front, in a last brush with politics for EDF investors. President Emmanuel Macron's government needs to get its budget for the nationalisation approved in parliament before moving ahead.

There's also a possibility that large asset managers, such as hedge funds, could come in and push for a better deal. Others, though, aren't waiting around.

Twitter wins its opening salvo against Musk

Elon Musk and Twitter will square off in a Delaware courtroom in October in what is primed to be the biggest deal battle in a generation.

Chancellor Kathaleen McCormick of the Delaware Court of Chancery is expediting a trial in which Twitter is seeking to force Musk to complete his $44bn takeover of the social media company.

Phalanxes of bankers, lawyers and public relations handlers will shuttle to the state, or take refuge in the Hotel Du Pont for a first-hand account.

In asking for an expedited trial, Twitter had argued that the uncertainty over the takeover was harming its business.

“It's attempted sabotage,” Bill Savitt, Twitter's lead lawyer at Wachtell Lipton, said during Tuesday's hearing. “He is doing his best to run Twitter down . . . and he's doing that as a way to try to get out of the contract he promised to consummate.”

Musk hoped to hold a trial in early 2023, after his lawyers investigated bot activity on the social network.

His lawyer, Andrew Rossman at Quinn Emanuel, argued that analysing Twitter's bots required investigating billions of data points that could take many months.

McCormick ultimately favoured Twitter's arguments. “The reality is that the delay threatens irreparable harm to the sellers,” she said.

It is an early win for Twitter.

“Twitter is trying to decide this now because they think moving quickly is to their advantage,” Eric Laumann, head of North American risk arbitrage research at Oscar Gruss, told DD.

“Musk is at his weakest right now,” he said, noting that the mercurial billionaire now faces a time crunch in building his case.

Job moves

  • JPMorgan Chase has named J&J former chief executive Alex Gorsky as director to its board.

  • Todd Leland has been named president of Goldman Sachs International, reporting to the unit's chief executive Richard Gnodde. Leland will relocate from Hong Kong to London where he was co-head of the bank in the Asia Pacific region.

  • Francesco Ciardi has joined investment firm Stonepeak as a London-based managing director. He was previously at hedge fund Elliott Management, where he was an associate portfolio manager and worked for the past nine years.

  • GLP has named former Microsoft executive Jennifer Weitzel as president of its global data centre business.

  • Clearlake Capital Group has announced several senior executive promotions including Arta Tabaee to partner and managing director.

The experience she gained as one of Berkshire's youngest executives inspired the creation of her own firm, according to the New York Times.
